qas.question: Which Houses in the UK must approve a bill before it is assented?

answers.text: House of Commons and the House of Lords

qas.question: Which Parliamentary Acts allow a bill to be presented for assent even after the House of Lords has refused it?
Who can be authorized to grant assent by letters patent?

answers.text: the sovereign or by Lords Commissioners

qas.question: What is presented for royal assent in the US?

plausible_answers.text: direct that a bill be presented for assent

qas.question: Under the Parliament Acts of 1917 and 1949, the House of Commons may do what?

plausible_answers.text: by the sovereign or by Lords Commissioners

qas.question: Each house must be notified jointly before what?

context: In the United Kingdom, a <b3_0>bill<b3_0/> is presented for royal assent after it has passed all the required stages in both the <a0_0>House of Commons and the House of Lords<a0_0/>. Under the <a1_0>Parliament Acts 1911 and 1949<a1_0/>, the House of Commons may, under certain circumstances, <b4_0>direct that a bill be presented for assent<b4_0/> despite lack of passage by the House of Lords. Officially, assent is granted <b5_0>by <a2_0>the sovereign or by Lords Commissioners<b5_0/><a2_0/> authorised to act by letters patent. It may be granted in parliament or outside parliament; in the latter case, each house must be separately notified before <b6_0>the bill takes effect<b6_0/>.
